metadata.case_name: State of Bombay v. First Respondent

facts.text: First respondent presented plaint on 6th February 1950 to Prothonotary of Bombay High Court for summary suit against second respondent to recover Rs. 11,704-2-4 on promissory notes.
Suit instituted in High Court contravening notification dated 20th January 1950 under Section 4 of Bombay City Civil Court Act, under which suits up to Rs. 25,000 to be heard by City Civil Court.
Plaint stated High Court had jurisdiction as Act and notification ultra vires.
Learned Judge in Chambers on 23rd February 1950 admitted plaint holding Section 4 ultra vires.
State of Bombay impleaded as defendant on application of Advocate-General; proceedings transferred to Division Bench.
Division Bench (Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.) on 29th March 1950 held Act intra vires but Section 4 void as delegation; suit properly laid in High Court.
Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) came into force on 10th May 1948 to establish additional civil court for Greater Bombay.
Section 3: City Civil Court has jurisdiction over suits of civil nature not exceeding Rs. 10,000 arising in Greater Bombay, subject to exceptions.
Section 4: State Government may by notification invest City Court with jurisdiction up to Rs. 25,000.
Section 12: High Court shall not have jurisdiction over suits cognisable by City Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948), is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay
Whether in any event Section 4 of the above Act is ultra vires the State Legislature
Whether the Bombay High Court has jurisdiction to try the suit

petitioner_arguments.text: Act is intra vires under entry 1 List II (administration of justice, constitution and organisation of courts); includes power to confer general jurisdiction on courts constituted by province.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 1 List II, Government of India Act 1935; Section 9 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Entry 2 List II and entry 53 List I confer special powers for jurisdiction re matters in their lists, not limiting general jurisdiction under entry 1.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entries 1,2 List II; 53 List I, GOI Act 1935

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4 is conditional legislation, not delegation; legislature fixed policy (initial Rs.10,000, max Rs.25,000), left timing to government.

respondent_arguments.text: Act ultra vires as confers jurisdiction on new court not only for List II matters but also List I (e.g. promissory notes, entry 28 List I).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 53 List I, 28 List I, GOI Act 1935

respondent_arguments.text: Entries 53 List I, 2 List II, 15 List III limit jurisdiction to matters in respective lists; entry 1 List II excludes jurisdiction.
Section 4 delegates legislative power to Provincial Government to decide jurisdiction up to Rs.25,000.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar (1949 FCR 595)

court_reasoning.text: Administration of justice (entry 1 List II) includes jurisdiction and powers of courts; provincial legislature can invest courts with general civil jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expressions in entry 1 wide enough to include power and jurisdiction; entry 2 for special jurisdiction re List II matters.

court_reasoning.text: Entries 2 List II, 53 List I allow special/additional jurisdiction or barring re their list matters; does not oust general jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislative practice pre-1935 continued; courts had general jurisdiction subject to special laws.

court_reasoning.text: Pith and substance of Act is constitution of court and administration of justice (List II); incidental encroachment on List I immaterial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce supports.

court_reasoning.text: Section 4 valid conditional legislation; legislature determined policy (Rs.10k initial, up to 25k max), government decides timing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Queen v. Burah; not delegation as no discretion on what law shall be.

court_reasoning.text: High Court lacks jurisdiction per Section 12; suit cognisable by City Civil Court.

holdings.text: Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 intra vires Provincial Legislature under entry 1 List II.
Section 4 intra vires; conditional legislation, not invalid delegation.
Bombay High Court has no jurisdiction; City Civil Court has jurisdiction over suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd., Khulna
precedents_cited.relevance: Pith and substance doctrine; incidental encroachment on federal field.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Not applicable; no modification or re-enactment power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah
precedents_cited.relevance: Act intra vires under entry 1 List II.
Legislature can make law conditional on future event.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Establishes City Civil Court with general civil jurisdiction up to specified pecuniary limits; bars High Court jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Distributes legislative powers; Provincial power over administration of justice includes general jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Courts have jurisdiction over all civil suits except barred; supports general jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside. Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 and Section 4 held intra vires. Suit not maintainable in High Court; to be tried by City Civil Court.
outcome.relief_granted: State of Bombay succeeds; suit returned to City Civil Court.

key_quotes.text: "the expressions administration of justice and constitution and organization of courts, which have been used therein without any qualification or limitation, are wide enough to include the power and jurisdiction of courts"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on scope of entry 1 List II.

key_quotes.text: "Legislation, conditional on the use of particular powers, or on the exercise of a limited discretion, entrusted by the Legislature to persons in whom it places confidence, is not uncommon thing"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Queen v. Burah; validates Section 4.

key_quotes.text: "Once it is determined that the pith and substance is money-lending, is the extent to which the federal field is invaded a material matter? ... No"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Pith and substance doctrine applied to uphold Act.
